entry.et: Middle English, from Old English nū; akin to Old High German nū now, Latin nunc, Greek nyn

def.dt: :at the present time or moment
:in the time immediately before the present thought of them just now
:in the time immediately to follow :forthwith come in now

dt.un: used with the sense of present time weakened or lost to express command, request, or admonition now hear this now you be sure to write
used with the sense of present time weakened or lost to introduce an important point or indicate a transition (as of ideas) now, this may seem reasonable at first

def.dt: :sometimes now one and now another
:under the present circumstances
:at the time referred to now the trouble began
:by this time has been teaching now for twenty years
:in view of the fact that :since often followed by that now that we are here
:the present time or moment been ill up to now
:of or relating to the present time :existing the now president
:excitingly new now clothes
:constantly aware of what is new now people the now generation
National Organization for Women
:from time to time :occasionally now and then we go off to the country
:the present time used with the man's obligation is in the here and now W. H. Whyte
:right away
:at present

entry.et: Middle English everich, every, from Old English ǣfre ǣlc, from ǣfre ever + ǣlc each

def.dt: :being each individual or part of a group without exception
:being each in a series or succession every few days every once in a while
:being all taken severally
:being each within a range of possibilities was given every chance
:complete entire we have every confidence in her
:at intervals :occasionally
